# Main findings {.inverse auto-animate="true"}

<br>

::: {.textcenter}
We have summaried over [75,000 vegetation assemblages]{.text-color-highlight-primary} in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by [9 ecosystem properties]{.text-color-highlight-secondary}. We have also included over [150,000 radiocarbon dates]{.text-color-highlight-human} derived from archaeological data and [4 past climate variables]{.text-color-highlight-climate}.
:::

## Main findings {.inverse auto-animate="true"}

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

<br>

::: {.textcenter}
This is the first study to [quantitatively]{.text-color-highlight-primary} estimate the relative importance of [human]{.text-color-highlight-human} and [climate]{.text-color-highlight-climate} effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-color-highlight-secondary}.
:::


## Main findings {.inverse auto-animate="true"}

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray} 
This is the first study to quantitatively estimate the relative importance of human and climate effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

<br>

::: {.textcenter}
[Localy]{.text-color-highlight-primary}, [humans]{.text-color-highlight-human .bold} had [severe impact]{.text-color-highlight-tertiary} on vegetation change during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-color-highlight-secondary}.
:::

## Main findings {.inverse auto-animate="true"}

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray}
We have summaried over 75,000 vegetation assemblages in over 1260 fossil pollen records. Decribe each ecosystem by 9 ecosystem properties. We have also included over 150,000 radiocarbon dates derived from archaeological data and 4 past climate variables.
:::

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray} 
This is the first study to quantitatively estimate the relative importance of human and climate effects on vegetation properties globaly and during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

::: {.textcenter .text-color-gray}
Localy, humans had severe impact on vegetation change during the early-to-mid Holocene.
:::

<br>

::: {.textcenter}
[At a larger scale]{.text-color-highlight-primary}, [climate]{.text-color-highlight-climate .bold} was the [main driver]{.text-color-highlight-tertiary} of vegetation change during the early-to-mid [Holocene]{.text-color-highlight-secondary}.
:::
